title: Intro to Federalism - US Legal System & Voluntary Governance
author: marsresident / Van Kush Family
overview: Explanation of Federalism as the foundation of US Constitution, the three types of law, and distinction from Personal Law systems

revolutionary_foundation.premise: United States was founded on a Revolution
revolutionary_foundation.jefferson_perception: Many believed Thomas Jefferson was an Anarchist because he created moments of Anarchy

liberty_symbols.sic_semper_tyrannis: As Always to Tyrants - assassination theme

revolution_misconception.reason: Communist Manifesto is relatively new in Human History
revolution_misconception.historical_truth: Most Revolutions were about Liberty, based on Plato's Republic

federalism_core_concepts.definition: The idea behind the United States Constitution
federalism_core_concepts.no_ruling_class: No one is in charge here
federalism_core_concepts.accountability: Anyone can be taken out of office (no Assassination necessary)

faction_acknowledgment.premise: No one is probably right about Politics, Religion, etc.
faction_acknowledgment.solution: Government acknowledges all Factions, works to make everything equal for all

current_problems.teaching_failure: Can't figure out how to teach Shias and Sunnis about Federalism
current_problems.oversimplification: We think it's just all about Voting and Democracy

faction_hijacking.republicans_democrats: Are Factions - don't do anything that lasts Centuries
faction_hijacking.may_be_downfall: May even be the downfall of America

current_problems.lincoln_example: Called himself Republican but was a Federalist who preserved the Union
current_problems.state_of_union: Now we have 'State of the Union Address'

federalism_vs_personal_law.source: Yale Law paper 'Slicing the American Pie'

personal_law_system.how_it_works: Every Religion has their own rights
personal_law_system.example_rule: Muslims allowed multiple wives, Christians aren't

american_federalism.variation: Colorado Law different from Texas different from New York different from California
american_federalism.unity: All Submit to Constitution and Supreme Court

federalism_vs_personal_law.key_insight: Federalism is literally the Legal System we operate under as a Nation

fundamental_law.function: Sets up Rules for President, Courts, Congress
fundamental_law.significance: Makes those people have a job - gives them their Contract
fundamental_law.contract_theory: If they violate the Contract, it can be invalidated and replaced

statutory_law.what_it_is: Law that Constitution says Congress can write
examples: Commerce between States, Indian Tribes, Foreign Nations
statutory_law.codification: Acts of Congress codified into USC

case_law.significance: Supreme Court has been seeing cases for 300 years
case_law.evolution: Constitution becomes more clearly defined through situations
case_law.importance: Absolutely not least - this is where interpretation lives

legal_system_problems.appearance: Seems like lawyer doesn't do much, Judge makes Arbitrary decisions
legal_system_problems.reality: Takes time and effort to go through years of Case Law

lazy_practice.what_lawyers_do: Look at what happened in that County over past 5 years
lazy_practice.what_they_should_do: Read all those books Cover to Cover, highlighting profound material

legal_system_problems.good_lawyer: Might try to see if Judge will answer motion to Dismiss

writ_writers.definition: Someone who can write a Writ
writ_writers.expectation: Every lawyer should be able to write a Writ
writ_writers.reality: Almost every single Writ Writer in America started as Jailhouse Lawyer
writ_writers.jailhouse_lawyer: Someone who was in Jail and learned Law there, not from Law School
writ_writers.search_tip: Look up 'Writ Writers' on Google - brings up people who learned Law from inside Jail

quiz_questions.q: What are the three forms of law in America?
quiz_questions.a: Fundamental Law (Constitution), Statutory Law (Acts of Congress), Case Law (court decisions)
quiz_questions.explanation: Case Law is 'the REAL Law' - 300 years of interpretation

quiz_questions.q: How does Federalism differ from Personal Law systems like India?
quiz_questions.a: In Federalism, States are the 'personal' part; in Personal Law, religions have different rights
quiz_questions.explanation: India: Muslims can have multiple wives, Christians can't. US: Colorado law differs from Texas law

quiz_questions.a: Called himself Republican but was a Federalist who preserved the Union
quiz_questions.explanation: Republicans/Democrats are factions that may be the downfall of America

quiz_questions.a: People who can write Writs - almost all started as Jailhouse Lawyers who learned law in prison
quiz_questions.explanation: They learned from doing, not from Law School

quiz_questions.q: What is the core principle of Federalism?
quiz_questions.a: Voluntary governance with no ruling class, acknowledging all factions equally
quiz_questions.explanation: 3 competing branches, anyone can be removed from office
